docs.lead_paragraph: Nicole, a high school junior with short brown hair, soft eyes and a delicate chin, has smoked marijuana since she was 13 years old. Many of her friends at her Massachusetts high school use it too, and sometimes her father joins her. ''I smoke weed with my dad,'' Nicole, who is now 16, said. ''Obviously he feels fine about it. Since I started smoking weed, we've gotten closer.'' Marijuana has become so routine that Nicole admitted, ''I smoke every single day.''

headline.main: Teen-Agers Find Drugs Easy to Obtain and Warnings Easy to Ignore

docs.abstract: Interviews with 30 teen-agers in New York and Massachussetts suggest marijuana use among young appears to be increasing, perhaps at even higher rate that recent reports suggest; many say Pres Bill Clinton is example of adult drug use; charts; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 1 this morning, in the smudgy darkness of Salazar Park, Crisanto Campos was waiting patiently for a bus that would make him this country's latest version of a Freedom Rider, on a journey that would end in what Latino organizers are calling La Marcha, the march. Mr. Campos and several dozen others set out today from predominantly Hispanic East Los Angeles to join a rally behind the White House this Saturday, which organizers hope will draw a hundred thousand people for the largest Hispanic civil rights march in American history.

headline.main: Hispanic Groups Prepare To March to Washington

docs.abstract: Hispanic groups from East Los Angeles prepare to march to Washington to join rally behind White House on Oct 12, which organizers hope will be largest Hispanic civil rights march in American history; rally is meant to bring some unity to Latino ranks at time when national and local politicians are showing increasingly anti-immigrant bent; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Tony Catizone, 66, tried a widely used blood pressure drug, the result was disaster: His pressure soared and he had a stroke. Yet after a hospital doctor prescribed a newer drug that kept his pressure at safe levels, his mail order pharmacy, to save 30 cents a day, switched the retired Chicago city worker back to the first medication without telling the doctor. The switch was discovered by Mr. Catizone's son, Carmen, a Chicago pharmacist and an official of a national board of pharmacists, and he made sure that his father stayed with the hospital prescription. ''Luckily, I caught it,'' he said.

headline.main: Drug Substitutions Add to Discord Over Managed Care

docs.abstract: Managed care drug plans, seeking to cut costs, routinely switch patients from widely prescribed but expensive drugs to lower-priced alternatives, causing medical complications for some patients; many states allow substitutions if patented drug is replaced by generic copy, or if patient's doctor signs off; but some doctors feel pressured to give quick approval rather than spend hours fighting with HMO's; 50 million Americans are covered by restrictive drug plans under managed care; critics claim medical decisions are being dictated by deal between drug makers and health plans, though little research is available on how often sustituting one drug for another may cause harm; practice of switching prescriptions is coming under attack from American Medical Assn and pharamcist groups as potentially dangerous interference with patient care; photos; charts (L)
